awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SusChEM: Engineering the thermotolerant yeast Kluyveromyces marxianus for the synthesis of biobased chemicals
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to develop the yeast Kluyveromyces marxianus as a platform microorganism for industrial biomanufacturing. A critical area of the US industrial biotechnology sector is the conversion of biomass and other renewable feedstocks to high value and commodity chemicals. K. marxianus can grow at high temperature in high acidity, and on a wide range of different sugars.  These are important traits for economic bioprocesses. The project will develop new genetic engineering tools for this yeast and apply these tools to engineer the bio-production of two important classes of chemicals that are traditionally produced from petroleum feedstocks. The project will also contribute to the training of graduate and undergraduate students, as well as the development of new educational outreach programs for high school and community college students from diverse backgrounds.

The overall goal is to establish K. marxianus as a platform host for the production of a broad range of biobased chemicals. Critical to advancing K. marxianus is the development of new synthetic biology tools that can rapidly create strains with multiple genome edits and that can accurately control transcription of native and heterologous genes. This project addresses these challenges by (1) developing new enabling tools and methods for rapid strain development and genome engineering in this yeast species, and (2) applying the tools for metabolic engineering of pathways leading to commercially significant native (acetate esters) and non-native (polyketide) products. Phenylethyl and isoamyl acetate are valuable fragrance/flavor compounds and are used as industrial solvents. Polyketides have significant value as pharmaceuticals, including as antibiotic, anticancer, and cholesterol-lowering drugs. The rationale behind this project is that K. marxianus is a highly promising microbial host for non-aseptic (and aseptic) bioprocesses that can convert a range of different sugars into high-value and industrially-relevant chemicals and proteins. This research is transformational because it develops new synthetic biology tools and metabolic engineering approaches to harness and enhance the native traits of K. marxianus, enabling new bioprocesses for the conversion of renewable feedstocks to valuable products.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of the project was to develop the thermotolerant yeast Kluyveromyces marxianus as a platform host for industrial bioprocessing. Robust eukaryotic microorganisms that are genetically accessible, can grow at high temperature and low pH, and can grow well on a wide range of different sugars are needed to sustain technological and economic growth. Native strains of K. marxianus possess these important traits. In addition, this yeast species has twice the growth rate of traditional Baker?s yeast; rapid growth is another important industrial attribute. In this research, we developed new synthetic biology tools to enable efficient engineering of K. marxianus; these include promoters to control gene expression, high-efficiency CRISPR systems for genome engineering, genome-wide gRNA knockout libraries to create new strains and identify critical genes, and metabolite sensors to select promising strain variants. We implemented the tools to increase the synthesis of important products, particularly those built from the common precursor acetyl-CoA. A focus of the work was the synthesis of polyketides, which have significant value as pharmaceuticals and for biobased chemical production. Extensive metabolic engineering was used to increase polyketide synthesis in a group of K. marxianus strains. Intracellular enzyme colocalization strategies via organelle or RNA scaffolding were also shown to be effective for increasing synthesis of the desired products. This work has further established K. marxianus as platform yeast host that is both genetically accessible and has multiple attributes that enable low-cost bioprocessing. Many of the approaches in the work are readily extendable to other yeast species and microorganisms. The research has also contributed to the training of students at multiple levels and in underrepresented groups, and the results have been incorporated into educational materials.


Last Modified: 10/26/2023
Modified by: Nancy A Da Silva
